job_title: Introductory Chemistry I: Structure and Bonding
application_procedure: UTSC: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/
duties: Successful applicants will: attend in-person training and weekly organizational meetings with the supervisor; supervise up to 24 students in an in-person environment; read the lab manual and relevant material to deliver a pre-lab talk for each experiment; demonstrate lab set-ups; evaluate student preparation via marking lab notebooks; grade post-lab assignments and lab exams; maintain attendance and marks records; attend benchmarking session training for marking writing assignment.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Applicant must have completed an undergraduate degree with a major or specialist in chemistry and have an excellent foundational knowledge of core chemistry principles including quantum model of the atom, modern bonding theory, and solution chemistry;  however, senior undergraduate chemistry students at UTSC who have completed CHMB16H3 and at least one B-level CHM course with a lab may also be considered. Applicant should be familiar with basic lab techniques such as titrations, weighing by difference, and preparing calibration curves. Applicant should be comfortable with using technology such as Microsoft Teams or Zoom. 

The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.

application_procedure: To apply, please email your CV and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT135S"
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator. Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs. The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate. If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach. In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment. Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter. TA must have previous experience with, and training on, operating rotating machines, as well as with operating higher voltage live circuitry (>100V). Candidate must have a strong grasp of space vectors and space vector control of the synchronous machine. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: ECE1049 provides an in-depth exploration of Electric Vehicle (EV) technology, focusing on the key components, systems, and challenges in modern electric mobility. The course covers concepts of electric propulsion systems, battery technologies, power electronics, and charging infrastructure. TAs will conduct hands-on labs, which includes testing and integrating EV subsystems. TAs should have good knowledge and understanding of the Energy Systems environment and courses such as ECE314. TAs who have taken ECE11049 or worked on the EV setups are strongly encouraged to apply.

application_procedure:
Applicants should include a cover letter, current curriculum vitae (including previous teaching evaluations (if applicable)), a statement of teaching philosophy, and the names and contact information of three referees by December 10, 2025.
Natalie Crown, Director, PharmD Program
E-Mail: academichr.phm@utoronto.ca
duties:
Course description:
This course surveys the economic aspects of the pharmaceutical sector. The course will use the methods of economic analysis to investigate how markets allocate resources, when they work well and the role for government when they do not work well. Specific topics include the economics of the development of new drugs; economic aspects of drug insurance, economic appraisal of new drugs (“pharmacoeconomics”); and economic models of the pharmacist labour market.

Duties
•	Teaching and developing up to 24 hours of content
•	Coordinating teaching assistants, midterm(s), and final exam marking.
•	Coordinating guest lecturers, midterm(s), and final exam marking.
•	All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a University credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content and assessments; providing a list of relevant reading materials.
•	Prepare, organize, and delivery of course material, preparation and delivery of assignments; be available to students seeking assistance between classes; evaluate and provide students with feedback on their work.
Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Applicants should at a minimum, possess PhD and familiarity with content area including:
•	Principles of economics and their applications in the health sector
•	Economic aspects of the community pharmacy sector in Canada
•	Methods of economic analysis to  investigate how markets allocate resources, when they work well and the role for government when they do not work well
•	Pharmacoeconomics
qualifications_preferred:

•	Knowledge of the Quercus platform for online course delivery is required and experience in online teaching is an asset.
•	Teaching or TA experience in course with similar content.

application_procedure:
Please apply on FASE Teaching Assistant Management System (TAMS):

https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/877

Your application must include (1) a brief statement of interest detailing how your background meets the requirements for the role, as well as (2) a resume or CV in PDF format, that describes your qualifications for the position. If you have any questions about the position, please email both Philip Asare (philip.asare@utoronto.ca) and Morgan Hooper (morgan.hooper@utoronto.ca). If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Diane Giang at director.engsci@utoronto.ca.
course_enrolment: ~250 - total enrollment - each tutorial is approx. 24 students
duties:
TAs in ESC204 are responsible for leading one or two weekly design studio (tutorial and practical) sections, supporting in-lecture workshops and active learning activities, and assessing and providing feedback on student work. They must also attend regular weekly meeting(s), as well as several additional meetings (to be scheduled at the beginning of the term) related to grading assignments. To support these varied activities, course-specific training will be offered in December 2025.

Studios (2-hour tutorial and practical blocks consisting of approximately 24 students which meet twice weekly) mainly involve activities related to engineering design, and help students build skills around effective teamwork, project management, understanding unfamiliar design contexts and stakeholders, technical design and prototyping, and communication. For technical design and prototyping, TAs will also facilitate interactions between students and course partners such as the Myhal Fabrication Facility during studio: https://uoft.me/myfab. In addition, TAs will give feedback on (asynchronously) and approve student orders for parts and services from the Fabrication Facility outside of studio time. 

Each TA is expected to support one or two studio sections. There is some flexibility in exactly which section(s) you are assigned to accommodate your availability, but you will have to be available for both meeting times for your assigned section(s) each week. In addition to leading studio sessions, TAs will assess oral presentations (during studio) as well as written and other multi-media student work, including CAD models, sketches, videos and photographs of mechatronic systems, circuit diagrams, functional block diagrams, project management documentation, and other design-relevant artifacts. As part of all assessments, TAs are expected to provide constructive, actionable feedback to students to help them improve from deliverable to deliverable.

All TAs are also required to attend weekly course team meetings (two per week for the first six weeks, and one per week thereafter). Weekly course team meetings will include a debrief of the previous week’s studio activities, plans for the following week’s studio activities, lecture content overviews, and discussion of any problems that may have arisen. Meetings will be held in hybrid format with in-person attendance required except by prior arrangement. In addition, you will be required to attend some lectures to assist students with hands-on teamwork and active learning activities during lecture, and/or hold "Prototyping Support Hours" in the Myhal Light Fabrication Facility to support ongoing prototyping work.

TAs will be supported by faculty co-leads, an engineering communication instructor, and will work together to share duties relating to course logistics as part of a large, tight-knit TA team.

Studio sessions, meetings and lectures are planned to be held in-person, unless there are changes to health policies that prevent in-person course delivery. Lectures will be delivered in hybrid format for accommodation reasons; however, you must plan to attend lecture in-person as needed to support active learning. Any changes to the course delivery (in-person, online, or a hybrid of both), will be communicated by the University at a later date. 

All TAs are required to complete all components of the Myhal Fabrication Facility Safety Training (Tier-1 and Tier-2): https://uoft.me/myfabsafety.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Open to graduate students who have an APSC B.A.Sc. or equivalent, and to qualified upper year APSC undergraduate students. Students who (1) have taught or assisted in design course(s), (2) have worked on design projects with global/international context, impact or significance, (3) have prior experience with (course-based or from industry) teamwork and project management, (4) have competencies in one or more of the following technical areas (including adapting to new software/tools and navigating documentation/resources within these areas): system-level electrical circuit design (e.g.: for powering embedded systems; for signal conditioning; for interfacing microcontrollers, sensors, actuators, and digital input/output); embedded system/microcontroller programming and interfacing including familiarity with MicroPython or CircuitPython; computer programming for system development and/or data analysis (Python, MATLAB preferred); mechanical and/or mechatronic design (including CAD, casing design, and/or mechanical actuation) o traditional fabrication methods (wood and/or metalworking); digital fabrication methods (3D printing and/or laser cutting and/or CNC) or internet-of-things (IoT).
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to students who engage in and have a passion for Engineering Design, as well as (1) have taken ESC101, ESC102, ESC203 and ESC204, (2) have been or are currently enrolled in Engineering Science.
tutorial:
Studio TAs must be available during at least one "Studio Block" (same-numbered TUT and PRA sections, 4 hours each week), as well as during select lecture and meeting times (1-5 hours each week, meetings to be determined based on team schedules). At this time, we are hiring for the following studio blocks:

Block 1
Wednesdays 9am-11am
AND
Fridays 9am-11am

Block 2
Tuesdays 12pm-2pm
AND
Thursdays 2pm-4pm

duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator. Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs. The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate. If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach. In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment. Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_preferred: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

application_procedure:
Application Process
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. The deadline to submit your application is November 18, 2025. For more information, you may contact:
Angela Niazmand
Undergraduate and TA Administrator
Department of Statistical Sciences
University of Toronto
700 University Avenue
Ontario Power Building - 9160-6
Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5
www.statistics.utoronto.ca
E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties. Providing lectures from prepared notes for all sections for 1-2 weeks
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed a senior undergraduate course in regression analysis covering course topics or equivalent
o	Experience in conducting linear regression analysis, including assessment and correction of assumptions and appropriate model diagnostics
o	Experience performing statistical analyses and data manipulation in R and R-Studio
o	Strong organizational skills and ability to maintain tactful communication with students
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience in report writing and statistical communication
o	Experience providing written and formative feedback to others or a demonstrated interest to develop such skills
o	Familiarity with scientific report structure and best practices
o	Experience answering a variety of student questions (e.g., debugging code, writing advice, writing proofs and problem solving, data analysis techniques)

qualifications_minimum: Applicants should have significant experience writing pthread-based concurrent programs and distributed programs using RPC. Applicants must have an in-depth understanding of broadcast protocols, consensus protocols, fault tolerance and consistency issues and replication methods in distributed systems. Applicants must have taken courses in operating systems and distributed systems. Applicants must have experience using Linux-based systems. application_procedure: Please submit your application form, resume and transcript to ortensia.qendro@utoronto.ca  For detailed information on the application process, visit: https://www.utm.utoronto.ca/mbiotech/about/current-opportunities
duties:
The TA will support the delivery of lectures and tutorials, assist with student learning, and help manage course logistics. The course covers topics such as feed-forward neural networks, convolutional and recurrent neural networks, optimization techniques, medical image processing, and natural language processing, all implemented in R using Keras. Duties include:

Create rubric and grading scheme for individual coding assignments, team projects and final exam

Grade individual coding assignments, team projects and final exam based on the rubric and grading scheme

Respond to student inquiries and provide academic support as needed
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Graduate-level training in machine learning, deep learning, or data science

Strong proficiency in R and RStudio, including experience with Keras

Experience with Python

Familiarity with health or biological datasets

Prior TA or teaching experience

Excellent communication and interpersonal skills

Experience with medical image analysis or text mining is an asset
qualifications_preferred: Same as Minimum Qualifications.

duties: The Head Teaching Assistant (Head TA) is responsible for coordinating and supporting all Teaching Assistants (TAs) assigned to the course, including those involved in labs, tutorials, marking, and invigilation (LTMI-TAs). The Head TA will oversee their performance and conduct, assign and schedule tasks, prepare the necessary documentations regarding TA duties, and provide training and guidance when needed. The Head TA ensures the smooth operation of all course components, including labs, tutorials, tests, and examinations, and responds to student inquiries related to administrative matters such as course platform access, lab/tutorial procedures, missed assessments, and remark requests. The Head TA will also participate in online discussion forums (e.g., Piazza), assign tutorial questions, coordinate room assignments for in-person tests, and manage the preparation, printing, distribution, and processing of test and exam materials (including Crowdmark setup and QR codes). Additional responsibilities include collecting and integrating marks for all assessments, assisting instructors with homework assignment planning, supporting the preparation and maintenance of course materials on Quercus, contributing to the calculation and finalization of course grades, and attending regular instructional team meetings. The Head TA may also be assigned other related duties as required to support the effective delivery and administration of the course.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Proficient knowledge in the physics of electricity and magnetism and circuit analysis. Must have prior experience as Head TA for very large courses.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

The application package for each course must include a single file in PDF format, containing Unit 1 completed application form available here, https://www.utm.utoronto.ca/iccit/media/1127/download?inline, cover letter, and resume. Please send your package to ICCIT Director email, ccitjobs@utoronto.ca.
duties: Marking position
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates must be enrolled in a graduate degree program at the University of Toronto and have equivalent experience specific to the subject matter. Must be familiar with Quercus. For marking positions, candidates must be able to work well under time constraints and meet deadlines.

department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure: To apply, please go to: https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/834. If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.
duties: Duties may include conducting tutorials /laboratory demonstrations and marking tutorial/laboratory work, problem sets, tests and examinations.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Knowledge in electric and magnetic fundamental laws - see course outline.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.
tutorial: Please refer to https://ttb.utoronto.ca/ for the most current course schedule.

application_procedure: apply through https://cupeha.utm.utoronto.ca/dept/umbio/app/ta
duties: Typical duties may include but are not limited to: attending meetings with supervisor, collating student’s marks across course sections and maintenance of Grade Centre on course LMS (Quercus, organizing student missed course components and medical notes, setting up & maintaining the course Quercus site, monitoring the Quercus discussion board and course inbox, consulting with students & responding to student emails, preparing tests & exams, marking exams, running scantrons, uploading marks, monitoring the TA marking of assignments, tests and exams
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A 4-year degree in Biology with appropriate background for the course to be demonstrated. Must be available to attend on-site as needed for invigilation, test processing and other duties as needed. Must have demonstrated expereince with listed Course administration tasks, Quercus, and prior experience in this course
qualifications_preferred: Preferred Qualifications include: academic qualifications, enrolment as a graduate student, previous TA experience, suitability for the position and appropriate background in the subject/specialty within the Department of Biology. Expereince using Corwdmark and with admin tasks in large courses preferred.
salery: $53.92 per hour (+4% vacation pay) Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, and Design
application_procedure: For detailed information, please refer to faculty website:  https://www.daniels.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities
duties: In this course, TAs will act as facilitators in discussion sections, take attendance, check student work for completeness, administer examinations, and act as record-keepers of student efforts in their respective sections. Typical duties include following along with course reading, attending required lectures and weekly teaching coordination meetings, grading papers and exams, and providing students with clarification and assistance as necessary.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Professionalism, organizational ability, comfort with public speaking and leading group discussions, knowledge of the history of global architecture, CGPA 3.0 or above. Please include in cover letter the courses the relevant courses taken.
qualifications_preferred: Strong writing skills, GPA above 3.5 in coursework related to the history and theory of architecture, landscape, and urbanism.

job_title: Caribbean Foodways Across History, Culture and Diaspora
application_procedure: Please e-mail your CV to Sarah Aleem (Business Officer) sarah.aleem@utoronto.ca
duties:
Grading quizzes, tests, assignments & exams, Meet with or respond to students’ inquiries during office hours,  Invigilate quizzes, tests & exams, Attend weekly lecture and/or review lecture material, Meetings when necessary to prepare for lectures
Assistance with lecture preparing and help with course structure and organization
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: See Preferred Qualifications
qualifications_preferred: Background in related material preferred
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Apply online at: https://tapp.cs.toronto.edu/hash/external/postings/pGMcAWNd6KTQQ6nenxJ2VnC8   For inquiries, contact: tacoord@cs.toronto.edu. In your application you will be asked to respond to a brief questionnaire and provide a CV.
duties: The nature of this position has both in-person and remote elements. Work with embedded ethics team to deliver and develop modules (designing case studies, planning breakout discussion activities, etc.) - Write parts of, proofread and edit project documents, including educational materials in Computer Science and Ethics. - Coordinate with project team via email and synchronous meetings - Review academic literature (in Computer Science Education and related fields) as references for research project.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: see preferred qualifications
qualifications_preferred: B.A. in Philosophy preferred or equivalent- Good prior knowledge of ethics, especially applied ethics - One year prior experience as a TA, normally in Philosophy department, at U of T - Ability to work collaboratively to develop effective teaching modules - Ability to promote engagement with and interest in ethics from students with no background or prior interest in philosophy. Preference in hiring goes to Philosophy graduate students (and not CS graduate students or students in other programs). CS students with minor or joint major in Philosophy during undergrad studies may apply.

application_procedure: All applications must be submitted to the Online Teaching Application at: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/
duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; holding regular office hours; supervising TAs assigned to course, if needed. Please note, the course will be offered in person.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Effective teacher: teaching experience is an asset. Well-organized and stimulating approach to subject. Applicants’ research area should be closely related to course material. Evidence of progress in Ph.D. program.
salery: Course Instructor (CUPE 3902) for half course - $9,442.98. First time Course Instructor (CUPE 3902) for half course -  $10,553.15 (includes additional stipend).

job_title: Course Instructor: The Changing Geography of Latin America
application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter, C.V. (including previous teaching evaluations (if applicable)), and names of two possible references by 5:00 p.m., on Friday, November 21, 2025. Applications should be sent to: OFFICE OF THE CHAIR, Department of Geography and Planning at email: jobs@geog.utoronto.ca.
duties: Preparing materials for lectures and class discussions; preparing course syllabi and selecting relevant readings; developing, administering, and marking course assignments, tests and exams; test/exam invigilation; holding regular office hours; planning and supervising the work of teaching assistants.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A PhD or a PhD in progress in Geography or a related field is required
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience teaching this or a similar course at the University level is preferred.
salery: $9,442.98 (Half Course); $10,553.15 (First CI Half Course, Inc. Additional Stipend)

Applications should be sent to: OFFICE OF THE CHAIR, Department of Geography and Planning at email: jobs@geog.utoronto.ca.
duties: Instructors will lecture on the themes of the course; prepare the syllabus and lectures; develop and administer grading, course assignments, tests and exams; mark and invigilate exams; hold regular office hours; and supervise teaching assistants. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A PhD or a PhD in progress in Geography or a related field is required. Knowledge of the course topics is required. Completion of a professional development course on teaching preferred.
qualifications_preferred: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
salery: $9,442.98 (Half Course); $10,553.15 (First CI Half Course, Inc. Additional Stipend)

department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure: To apply, please go to: https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/811. If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.
duties: Duties may include conducting tutorials /laboratory demonstrations and marking tutorial/laboratory work, tests, and examinations.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction
qualifications_preferred: Expertise in the analysis and design of systems employing radio waves, covering both the underlying electromagnetics and the overall system performance aspects such as signal-to-noise ratios: Transmission/reception phenomena; Propagation phenomena; receiver design aspects include: receiver figures of merit, noise in cascaded systems, noise figure, and noise temperature. Must understand system examples such as fixed wireless access; mobile and personal communication systems; satellite communications; radar.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.
tutorial: Please refer to https://ttb.utoronto.ca/ for the most current course schedule.

application_procedure: apply through https://cupeha.utm.utoronto.ca/dept/umbio/app/ta
duties: Typical duties may include but are not limited to: attending meetings with supervisor, collating student’s marks across course sections and maintenance of Grade Centre on course LMS (Quercus, organizing student missed course components and medical notes, setting up & maintaining the course Quercus site, monitoring the Quercus discussion board and course inbox, consulting with students & responding to student emails, preparing tests & exams, marking exams, running scantrons, uploading marks, monitoring the TA marking of assignments, tests and exams
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A 4-year degree in Biology with appropriate background for the course to be demonstrated. Must be available to attend on-site as needed for invigilation, test processing and other duties as needed. Must have demonstrated experience with listed Course administration tasks, Quercus, and prior experience in this course
qualifications_preferred: Preferred Qualifications include: academic qualifications, enrolment as a graduate student, previous TA experience, suitability for the position and appropriate background in the subject/specialty within the Department of Biology. Experience using Crowdmark and with admin tasks in large courses preferred.
salery: $53.92 per hour (+4% vacation pay) Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

duties:
May include student contact, marking/grading, other duties as required.

Please note this course is partnered with the Writing-Integrated Teaching (WIT) program. The WIT program helps instructors embed discipline-specific writing instruction into undergraduate courses to foster students’ writing development and success. As part of your TA duties, ~30 of your hours will be focused on supporting students’ writing. These tasks include receiving training on WIT-related topics (e.g., the importance of low-stakes writing, best practices for providing feedback on writing), attending benchmarking training sessions to focus on how to evaluate student assignments efficiently and fairly, holding designated office hours for writing assignments, and preparing/delivering writing instruction and resources during office hours.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Completion of TA training. Preference will be given to Psychology PhD students working within relevant research area groups.
qualifications_preferred: n/a

qualifications_minimum: APS360 is a first level machine learning/artificial intelligence software course. The course will focus on learning through implementation of machine learning systems in labs and a project. department: New College - Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
BPM338H1: An overview of mindfulness as a systematic investigation of subjective experience, with a survey of classic descriptions and contemporary scientific literature. Students will explore meditative practices in class and maintain a meditation practice outside class.

DUTIES: 
Holding office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking course assignments; attending lectures.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be familiar with topics and content addressed in the course, particularly in relation to the practices and theories of meditation and mindfulness.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants with an understanding of, or engaged in research related to, mindfulness meditation, Buddhist Studies and/or the interactions between Buddhism and Psychology.
tutorial: Lectures: Tuesdays 5:00 PM - 8:00 PM [Note: the course delivery mode is currently Online Synchronous and the successful applicant will need to be available to attend lectures]

application_procedure: Please submit your application via: https://lmp.forms-db.com/view.php?id=679711
duties: Teaching Assistants may expect to be involved in any of the following, as requested by the course coordinator: familiarize her/his/themselves with course material; set up and manage in-person course delivery; provide student tutorials if needed; help mark tests and assignments; assist in making lecture materials and tests available to students; administer course evaluation surveys; be available for student questions by e-mail; invigilate quizzes; send reminders to lecturers and students about upcoming commitments; be present at the day of lecture to help with setup; maintain the course Quercus page; prepare quiz packages; contribute to marking quizzes, paper presentations and help coordinating marking; host Q&A sessions for quiz preparation; help lead lab tour at local healthcare facilities; other duties as required. The course will be delivered in-person.  If public health circumstances change at the university, Zoom or an equivalent, will be used to continue course delivery on-line.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: MSc students in Life Sciences programs with a keen interest in biomedical and translational research.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to current LMP students.

department: Department of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry
application_procedure:
Please complete the TA Application here:https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/774
If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugradassist.chemeng@utoronto.ca
duties: Assist course instructor with the evaluation of course assignments related to laboratories including but not limited to grading laboratory reports and quizzes, providing feedback in a timely manner, and entering grades.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto with strong written and oral communication skills, strong laboratory skills, clear understanding of laboratory safety, experience working safely in an experimental chemistry laboratory and a demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should have strong foundational knowledge of organic and inorganic chemistry, instrumental analysis (IR, GC), and organic chemistry techniques (TLC, melting point apparatus, distillation, liquid-liquid extraction) as well as engineering communication. Candidates should also have experience with experimental design and should hold a bachelor's degree in Chemical Engineering, Chemistry, or Engineering Chemistry. Preference will be given to those with a background in Chemical Engineering due to the alignment with the course objectives and content.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience with marking and grading laboratory reports would be an asset.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto with strong written and oral communication skills and a demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should hold a bachelor's degree in engineering, with a degree in Chemical Engineering being preferred. Candidates must have familiarity and experience with the FEEL TM Hatchery Business methodology and cash flow projections, P&L and Balance Sheet working knowledge. Ability to support the development of Business Plans for new ventures.  The FEEL TM methodology for entrepreneurial human capital and venture formation is a model to develop student’s/founder’s skills and define tech start-ups with the creation of the FEEL TM House business plan, cash-flow projections and a three to six-minute "elevator" pitch.
qualifications_preferred:
Preference will be given to applicants with work experience in the following areas: Business Plan formulation and review
Worked at,or formed a Start-up company
Accounting/Finance/Organizational Behaviour
Strategic Planning
Marketing/Social Media/Promotions/Sales
Business Financing, lending, capital raise
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure:

application_procedure: To apply, please email your CV and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT235Y-SINIF".
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections.  The instructor will be a member of a coordinated team with a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator, the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.   Normally, classes and tutorials will be conducted synchronously online during the scheduled lecture and tutorial times, respectively. There should be no synchronous activities outside of the scheduled lecture and tutorial hours. Final Exam is expected to be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2020, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Recent previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course is an asset.

job_title: An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning and Data Science
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. 
The deadline to submit your application is September 26, 2022. For more information, you may contact: Angela Niazmand, Undergraduate and TA Administrator, Department of Statistical Sciences, University of Toronto
700 University Ave- Rm 9160- 6, Ontario Power Building, Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5, www.statistics.utoronto.ca, E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact
jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated. Duties will include any or all of the following: attending lectures, running 
tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on on-line discussion boards, participating in training 
sessions, meeting with the instructors, holding office hours, grading student homework including written reports, and 
assisting with grading of tests and exams.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior undergraduate students (third and fourth year) with strong background in statistics and exemplary communication skills may also be considered.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate student with strong background in statistics, as well as excellent communication and writing skills, and the ability to interact well with undergraduate students.
